did.abstract: The Henry Diltz Photographs (Rona Elliot Papers) consist of 25 11" x 14" color and black-and-white photographs from 1969 to 1988; all shot, printed, and signed by Henry Diltz. The color photographs include images of Paul and Linda McCartney (1971), the Doors in the window of the Morrison Hotel (1969), Jimi Hendrix at Woodstock (1969), Crosby Stills & Nash (1969), Jackson Browne (1974), Janis Joplin at Woodstock (1969), Stephen Stills in the snow (1970), Buffalo Springfield (1966), Blondie (1977), Bruce Springsteen in concert (1981, 1988), and Elvis Costello (1979). The black-and-white photographs include images of Frank Zappa (1971), Crosby, Stills, Nash & Young (1970), Tom Waits (1980), the Eagles (1978), Bruce Springsteen at the Hollywood Bowl (1981), Jerry Garcia and David Crosby (1971), Neil Young (1970, 1975), James Taylor (1969), Keith Richards (1979), The Who at Monterey Pop (1967), and the Mamas and Papas (1967).

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Henry Diltz is a world-renowned photographer and founding member of the Modern Folk Quartet (MFQ). Diltz, who is as much at home as a musician on tour, is a visual historian of the last four decades of popular music. The rapport he’s developed with his musician friends enables him to capture candid shots that convey a rare feeling of trust and intimacy with his subjects

For Diltz, the pictures began with a $20 second-hand Japanese camera purchased on tour with the MFQ. When the group disbanded, Diltz embarked on his photographic career with an album cover for The Lovin’ Spoonful. Despite his lack of formal training, he easily submerged himself in the world of rock photography.

For over 40 years, his work has graced hundreds of album covers and has been featured in books, magazines, and newspapers. His unique artistic style has produced powerful photographic essays of Woodstock , The Monterey Pop Festival, The Doors, Crosby, Stills, Nash & Young, Jimi Hendrix, and scores of other legendary artists. Diltz continues his distinguished career, generating new and vibrant photographs that inspire the rock and roll fan in each of us.
Henry Diltz is a partner in, and is exclusively published and represented by, the Morrison Hotel Gallery.

custodhist.head: Custodial History
custodhist.p: The Henry Diltz Photographs (Rona Elliot Papers) were purchased by Elliot from Diltz, and then received by the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame and Museum, Inc. as a gift from Elliot on September 20, 2011.
